item.title: Block Plugin Structure
item.dc:creator: ndiego
item.content:encoded:
Objective

The purpose of this post is to document the development of a plugin template, or boilerplate, that can be used to build advanced blocks for the new WordPress Gutenberg editor. I am largely writing this for myself as a reference guide for future use, but I hope it is helpful for others starting out in the post-Gutenberg world of WordPress.

Have recommendations, or think something should be done a different way? I am all ears, please leave a comment at the end of the post. Always looking to learn something new!

Some background...

As of writing, there are many tools out there that can help you build a block from scratch. Two that I have found most useful are:

  • create-guten-block by @AhmadAwais
  • Create Block by WordPress

One quick note about Create Block. It is now baked right into the Gutenberg project and is officially supported by WordPress. While Create Block contains significantly less features than create-guten-block, I would recommend starting there if you are looking to closely follow the "WordPress way" of doing things.

While both of these options can get you up and running quickly, they do not provide a robust platform on which to build an advanced block-related project. They are great starting points though. By playing with both, you can learn a lot about how blocks are designed to work in WordPress.

After doing more research, I stumbled upon CoBlocks, which is a collection of fantastic blocks that is freely available in the plugins repository and on GitHub. CoBlocks was originally founded by Rich Tabor and then was bought by GoDaddy in 2019. With over 200,000 downloads, I figured this would be a great codebase to explore. Furthermore, many of their developers are very active on the WordPress Slack channel and appear to be highly committed to adhering to, and promoting, WordPress coding standards. Therefore, much of the following will be based on the work done by the developers behind CoBlocks.

[Add note about project on github]

Table of Contents

  • Folder and file structure
  • package.json
  • webpack.config.js

Folder and file structure

my-plugin
├── dist/
│   └── index.js
│   └── editor.css
│   └── style.css
│   
├── includes/
│   ├── admin/
│   │       └── class-XXXX-block-assets.php
│   │
│   └── class-XXXX-block-assets.php
│
├── languages/
│   
├── src/
│   └── components/
│   │       └── edit.js
│   │       └── component-one.js
│   │       └── component-two.js
│   │       └── ...
│   ├── styles/
│   │       └── common.scss
│   │       └── editor.scss
│   │       └── style.scss
│   ├── block.json
│   ├── block.js
│   └── block.php
│
├── .editorconfig
├── .gitignore
├── my-plugin.php
├── LICENSE.txt
├── package.json
├── README.md
├── README.txt
└── webpack.config.js

Starting a new project with wp-create-block

Let's start with a little history. @wordpress/block was developed by

Tweaks to package.json

We want to add a few things to the package.json file that is created. 

"repository": {
    "type": "git",
    "url": "git://github.com/username/repository.git"
},
"homepage": "XXX",

Configuring webpack.config.js

We want to add two additional plugins that are not automatically included in the @wordpress/scripts package. These are the Mini CSS Extract Plugin (MCEP) and the Fix Style Only Entries Plugin (FSOEP). The MCEP extracts CSS into separate files and creates a CSS file per JS file which contains CSS. The FSOEP is a companion plugin that fixes a potential issue where an erroneous JS file is created when the MCEP is extracting the CSS. There is no need for the JS file, so the FSOEP removes this automatically for us.

Install both plugins as dependencies:

npm install --save-dev mini-css-extract-plugin webpack-fix-style-only-entries

With the MCEP comes the MiniCssExtractPlugin.loader, but we also need the following additional loaders:

  • css-loader
  • sass-loader

The css-loader is pretty straight forward to install, but the sass-loader also requires node-sass. This is the package that allows us to compile scss into css. So lets install these additional loaders and node-sass: 

npm install --save-dev css-loader sass-loader node-sass

Note that when installing sass-loader, you will likely get the following warnings. These can be ignored and are an issue with npm and not the functionality of the sass-loader itself.

npm WARN sass-loader@8.0.2 requires a peer of sass@^1.3.0 but none is installed. You must install peer dependencies yourself.
npm WARN sass-loader@8.0.2 requires a peer of fibers@>= 3.1.0 but none is installed. You must install peer dependencies yourself.

Now all the dependencies for our webpack configuration are installed. Next, we actually want to setup the webpack.config file. The end result should look something like this:

const path = require( 'path' );
const defaultConfig = require( '@wordpress/scripts/config/webpack.config' );

const MiniCssExtractPlugin = require( 'mini-css-extract-plugin' );
const FixStyleOnlyEntriesPlugin = require( 'webpack-fix-style-only-entries' );

module.exports = {
    ...defaultConfig,

    entry: {
        'index' : path.resolve( process.cwd(), 'src/index.js' ),
        'editor' : path.resolve( process.cwd(), 'src/styles/editor.scss' ),
        'style' : path.resolve( process.cwd(), 'src/styles/style.scss' ),
    },

    output: {
        filename: '[name].js',
        path: path.resolve( process.cwd(), 'dist/' ),
    },

    module: {
        ...defaultConfig.module,
        rules: [
            ...defaultConfig.module.rules,
            {
                test: /\.(sa|sc|c)ss$/,
                use: [
                    MiniCssExtractPlugin.loader,
                    'css-loader',
                    'sass-loader'
                ],
            }
        ]
    },

    plugins: [
        ...defaultConfig.plugins,

        new FixStyleOnlyEntriesPlugin(),
        new MiniCssExtractPlugin( {
            filename: '[name].css',
        } ),
    ],
};

Working with Git and SVN for publishing WP plugins

https://learnwithdaniel.com/2019/09/publishing-your-first-wordpress-plugin-with-git-and-svn/

block.js

block.php

The block.php file is the where you will register the block to the server and, if needed,

Support Files

.editorconfig

This file is used to apply coding standards to the text editor you are using, which in my case is Atom by GitHub. Visit editorconfig.org for more information about how to use an .editorconfig file in your text editor of choice. For Atom, a designated plugin is required. Simply install the EditorConfig package from the Atom Preferences screen. Note that you will likely get an error that the whitespace package, a core package of Atom, is interfering with the EditorConfig package. That is because they are both trying to do similar things. Disable whitespace and you are good to go.

The following is an example of what you will want your .editorconfig file to look like. It is based on the file provided in the CoBlocks project and adheres to the WordPress Coding Standards. 

# This file is for unifying the coding style for different editors and IDEs
# editorconfig.org

# WordPress Coding Standards
# https://make.wordpress.org/core/handbook/coding-standards/

root = true

[*]
charset = utf-8
end_of_line = lf
insert_final_newline = true
trim_trailing_whitespace = true
indent_style = tab

[*.yml]
indent_style = space
indent_size = 2

[*.md]
trim_trailing_whitespace = false

.gitignore

When using the template, you will want to find/replace the following:

  • Block Plugin Template
  • bpt_textdomain
  • BPT
  • bpt
  • BlockPluginTemplate
  • block_plugin_template
  • sampleBlock
  • sample-block

BPT

Used in the the global variables as well as JS function names.

Update Guide

  1. Update name of root folder to match the plugin you are building.
  2. webpack.config.js – Update bpt prefix on entry file names.
  3. package.json – Update the package name, version, description, author, repository and homepage fields.
  4. class-block-plugin-template.php – Complete the following updates:
    1. Update the main plugin information at top of file including the text domain, which is currently bpt_textdomain.
    2. Update the text domain throughout the entire file.
    3. Change the BPT prefix on the global definitions.
    4. If publishing to the wordpress.org, update the review url.
    5. Change the name on the main plugin class, currently BlockPluginTemplate and update every occurrence in the file.

Block Icons

It is recommended that you provide a custom icon for your blocks. The icons should in be SVG form.

Block Styles

blocks can have preset "styles" which are really just CSS classes that are applied to them. These styles add a UI element to the Inspector of each block. https://themeshaper.com/2019/02/15/customizing-gutenberg-blocks-with-block-styles/

When you are developing for WordPress, there is a good chance that you will run into a situation where you need to create custom image sizes. These can be particularly useful if you a build something the requires a very specific image dimensions, such as a slider or sidebar content area.

When you set a custom size, when a new image is uploaded to the Media Library, WordPress will automatically resize that image to the size you set.

Adding your own sizes is quite easy.

WordPress comes equipped with the four standard image sizes that are accessible from the admin screens. These are:

  • Thumbnail
  • Medium
  • Large
  • Full

In the new Gutenberg editor, then you add an image bock or a gallery, these are the only four sizing options that you will see.

item.title: Full Site Editing in WordPress – Building My First Block-Based Theme
item.dc:creator: ndiego
item.content:encoded:
Preface

Full Site Editing is slated to come to WordPress in version 5.8 later this year and I am quite excited. It undoubtedly represents a radical paradigm shift in the way we think about WordPress themes. No longer will themes need to build their own specialized solutions for managing headers, footers, sidebars, page templates, colors, typography and more. Everything will be accessible to the user directly from the core WordPress interface. As a result, the scope of what a theme "includes" will change dramatically.

While still very experimental, you can test out this new functionality in by installing the Gutenberg plugin and a block-based theme. I recommend the TT1 Blocks, which is a block-based version of Twenty Twenty-One. I have included a selection of resources at the end of this article that I found useful when learning about Full Site Editing.

Building a Block-Based Theme

In the past three weeks, I decided to dive head first into the world of Full Site Editing. I had not been keeping up with the project in Gutenberg, so I was approaching it with fresh eyes. My Block Visibility project needed a new website design and I thought it would be a good opportunity to explore this technology. Block Visibility is a plugin that harnesses the power of the Block/Site Editor. It would be a bit disingenuous if the website promoting the plugin wasn't a block-based theme, right?

I have always had a challenging time working from a blank canvas. Therefore, I decided to replicate the minimalistic theme here my personal website (this one) to get my feet wet. The original theme was build off underscores and was fairly complicated utilizing a ton of SASS files, templates, template parts, etc.

It is important to note that I am not an expert theme builder, and the original theme was far from optimized. I am not even linking the repository here since it's such a mess. But that was kind of the whole point of this exercise.

I spent a ton of time on the original design. So, how much effort and complexity would be required to rebuild it as a block-based theme?

Results

As a benchmark, the original theme had the following Lighthouse scores and total file size.

Original Theme

Theme Size

359kb

Number of Files

93

Lines of Code

6673

Outermost Theme (Block-based)

Theme Size

95kb (↓74%)

Number of Files

29 (↓69%)

Lines of Code

1645 (↓75%)

This analysis was thrown together rather quickly and but it illustrates how much smaller and simpler the Outermost theme is. FSE handles so much of the heavy lifting. On top of that, performance also increased slightly with no other modifications.

For reference, these are the active plugins currently on this website:

  • Akismet Anti-Spam – Anti-Spam for post comments and contact forms
  • Block Visibility – Used for content management and to dynamically hide/show specific content
  • Easy Plugin Stats – Fetches and displays plugin download counts and stats throughout the site
  • GitHub Updater – Manages theme updates from GitHub
  • Gutenberg – For all the latest FSE functionality
  • Jetpack by WordPress.com – Standard Jetpack "stuff"
  • Syntax-highlighting Code Block – Adds syntax-highlighting to all Code Blocks
  • Yoast SEO – Standard SEO suite

Issues

Moving to a block-based theme is not without it's issues. I have highlighted a few areas that still need development and that I struggled with when building my theme.

Navigation

If you look at this website on a mobile device, you'll notice that the main navigation is far from optional. At present, there is no mobile styling for the Navigation Block. I would like to see an option for a "hamburger" style button with a pop-out menu, or something similar for mobile devices.

A lot of work is being done on the Navigation Block. #27593 is a good reference ticket. However, there are so many use cases that the core block needs to accommodate, I expect we need to be a bit patient on this one.

Mobile Styles

Outside of the Media & Text Block, there is virtually no way to specify mobile styling in the Block Editor. There are a litany of third-party plugins and block libraries that aim to solve this problem, but having some mobile functionality baked into Core is needed. I would prefer not to have to download an entire block library to left-align an image on mobile that is right-aligned on desktop.

This complaint is predicated on nearly all styling options being available in the Site Editor. Of course these mobile tweaks can be added to the theme's stylesheet.

Spacing

I didn't realize how much I relied on very specific padding and margin combinations to achieve certain designs until I started trying to replicate content in the Site Editor. As it stands, only the Group and Cover blocks have spacing functionality, and it's limited to padding.

In the Outermost theme, I included a decent number of "helper classes" that are emblematic of Tailwind. Here are some examples for specifying margin. 

/* Margin utility classes */

.m-0 {
    margin: 0 !important;
}

.mt-0 {
    margin-top: 0 !important;
}

.mt-5 {
    margin-top: 5px !important;
}

.mt-10 {
    margin-top: 10px !important;
}

theme.json

Closing Thoughts

There were definitely times in this process that I was left frustrated. Often a bit of code would not work the way I thought it should. Official documentation on Full Site Editing is continually improving, but is still very limited. After scouring GitHub issues or Slack, I would invariably discover my problem was a bug or a missing feature in Gutenberg.

It's important to remember that Full Site Editing and block-based themes are experimental. You will find errors and your theme will break. But step away from your computer for a bit. When you come back and look at your work, you will be amazed at how little code it takes to develop a theme. It's an absolute joy to design a page visually in WordPress Core rather than some page builder plugin or manually in the code editor. With a suite of block patterns and templates at their disposal, I can only imagine clients will enjoy this as well. The potential for this platform is undeniable.

I do understand why not everyone is excited about Full Site Editing. As I mentioned at the onset of this article, it represents a massive paradigm shift in the WordPress ecosystem. We can't deny that Full Site Editing is an existential threat to many web design agencies that have invested heavily in theme development. These companies will be forced to adapt their business models or risk getting left behind.

That said, I firmly believe the future is bright. Give it a year or two. We will all look back on the pre-block days of WordPress as if it was the stone age. ????

Resources

The Theme Experiments repository is a great reference for existing block-based themes, and is where the development version of TT1 Blocks lives. I referred to it often when building my theme.

item.title: Preparing for WordPress 6.2 and improving workflows in the Icon Block 1.5.0
item.dc:creator: ndiego
item.content:encoded:
WordPress 6.2 is right around the corner, and with it comes several enhancements that directly impact custom block developers.

Enhancements

This release was a lot of fun, from SVG uploads and drop zones to adding support for new features in WordPress 6.2. Take a peek at the video below for an overview of the major enhancements in version 1.5.0 before diving into the details.

Insert icons from your Media Library

WordPress currently does not allow you to upload SVGs to the Media Library since this type of file can pose security concerns. While there have been ongoing discussions about allowing SVG uploads in Core, the best solution is to use a plugin like Safe SVG or to enable uploads using code.

Given the popularity of SVGs and the number of websites that have SVG uploads manually enabled, being able to insert icons from the Media Library was one of the top feature requests for the Icon Block.

I was always reticent about building out this feature. I did not want the block to enable SVG uploads itself. This type of functionality is beyond the scope of a single-block plugin. Therefore, I decided on a compromise.

If your website has SVG uploads already enabled, the Icon Block will allow you to insert icons from the Media Library. If SVG uploads are not enabled, the block will function as it always has in previous versions. This approach provides the best of both worlds without implementing inappropriate functionality for a block.

[image comparing the two]

How does it work?

When you insert an icon from the Media Library, the content of the SVG file is extracted and parsed. The plugin then adds the icon code to the block as a custom icon, and you can manage it just like any other custom icon.

This approach might sound strange. Why not insert an <img> tag linked to the URL of the SVG file? The answer is twofold.

First, the Icon Block is a static block. Meaning that even if the plugin is removed from your website, any existing blocks will still render on the front end, ensuring users will not have a broken experience. I wanted to retain this functionality if an SVG file was inadvertently deleted from the Media Library. This way, the block stores the actual SVG code rather than the URL of the uploaded file.

Second, converting an SVG file into a custom icon allows you to edit the SVG code from within the block. This functionality can be handy if you ever need to tweak the code, such as removing a hardcoded fill color. You no longer need to fix the SVG in your design application and reupload.

[gif of editing custom svg]

HOW I BUILT THIS

WordPress includes a number of components that make working with the Media Library much easier. I used the MediaUpload component to render upload buttons and applied the allowedTypes={ [ 'image/svg+xml' ] } property so that only SVG files are displayed when the Media Library modal opens. You can see the implementation for the block placeholder and the "Replace" dropdown on GitHub.

Since this functionality should only be allowed on sites with SVG uploads enabled, I needed to check if image/svg+xml was an allowed mime type before displaying the upload buttons. Thankfully, allowed types are accessible from the allowedMimeTypes Editor setting. See the code below, but note there is a small bug in WordPress 6.1 and lower where this setting returns null in the post Editor. The workaround is simple enough and will not be needed in the future once the minimum WordPress version is bumped to 6.2 and above.

// Allowed types for the current WP_User
const { allowedMimeTypes, mediaUpload } = useSelect( ( select ) => {
	const { getSettings } = select( 'core/block-editor' );

	// In WordPress 6.1 and lower, allowedMimeTypes returns
	// null in the post editor, so need to use getEditorSettings.
	const { getEditorSettings } = select( 'core/editor' );

	return {
		allowedMimeTypes: getSettings().allowedMimeTypes
			? getSettings().allowedMimeTypes
			: getEditorSettings().allowedMimeTypes,
		mediaUpload: getSettings().mediaUpload,
	};
}, [] );

Drop zones

Drop zones have been a personal feature request for quite some time. They allow you to drag and drop files onto the Editor and execute an action, which typically uploads the file. The native Image block in WordPress is a great example.

Working with custom SVGs in the Icon Block can become tedious. There are multiple steps involved with inserting an icon. First, you need to open the original SVG file in a text editor and copy the code. Then you must create a new block and open the custom icon modal. Finally, paste the code and insert the icon.

When it comes to working with custom SVGs in the Icon Block, the process can become quite tedious. There are several steps involved with inserting an icon. Firstly, you need to open the original SVG file in a text editor and copy the code. Then, you have to create a new block and open the custom icon modal. Finally, you can paste the code and insert the icon.

There are only two steps with drop zones. Add a new Icon Block to the Editor and then drag and drop the SVG file onto the block!

[image]

How does it work?

As discussed above, version 1.5.0 allows you to insert icons from the Media Library if SVG uploads are enabled. The drop zone in the Icon Block behaves similarly.

If SVG uploads are enabled, when you drop an SVG file onto the Icon Block, the file will be added to your Media Library. If SVG uploads are not enabled, the content of the dropped file is extracted and parsed. The plugin then adds the icon code to the custom icon modal, mirroring the steps you would take when manually adding a custom icon.

New block inspector tabs

In an attempt to declutter the block inspector panel, WordPress 6.2 breaks this panel into tabs. You can read more about this change in the official dev note.

HOW I BUILT THIS

The Icon Block registers native block supports for border and dimensions. Therefore, these controls are handled by WordPress and show up on the Styles tab. The remaining controls are custom, including the color settings, meaning they would appear on the Settings tab by default.

I decided that color controls should be moved to the Styles tab to match other Core blocks, and all other controls should stay on the Styles tab for now. To accomplish this, all I needed to do was wrap the code for the color controls in an InspectorControls component with the property group="styles".

<>
    <InspectorControls group="settings">
        ...
    </InspectorControls>
    <InspectorControls group="styles">
        ...
    </InspectorControls>
</>

Added style element support

When a custom icon is inserted using the Icon Block, the code is parsed to ensure it's a valid SVG. Before version 1.5.0, this process would remove any <style> tags within the SVG. While this behavior is fine for the vast majority of users, there are instances where you may want to allow <style> tags. A good example is the WordPress twentieth anniversary logos.

Note that you can also change the styles of your SVGs from within the custom icon editor. This can be handy if you need to make a quick change but don't want to recreate the SVG in your design application.

Bug Fixes

SVGs can be finicky, and WordPress is always changing. Therefore, each major release of the plugin typically includes a bug fix (or two).

Version 1.5.0, includes a fix

Fixed attribute parsing

Depending on the application you are using to create . This fix improves support for SVGs generated from Figma and other design tools.

That said, SVG files come in all shapes and sizes, and developing a solution to validate this code correctly one hundred percent of the time is seemly never complete. If you do ever find an issue, please log it on GitHub.

Looking Ahead

The Icon Block has achieved a significant milestone of reaching 10,000 active users, making it my third plugin to cross this threshold. What sets this achievement apart is that it's my only block-related plugin to do so (yet).

As the community continues to adopt blocks and block themes, I fully expect this number to continue growing steadily throughout 2023. It's a great time to be building block plugins.

As of version 1.5.0, many of the major feature requests have been implemented. I will continue exploring ways to make integrating the block with third-party icon libraries easier.

If there is something that you would like to see, feel free to add your own issues on Github. In the meantime, you can stay tuned for more updates by following @theiconblock or myself on Twitter.

item.title: When a block is just a block
item.dc:creator: ndiego
item.content:encoded:
I have been building WordPress blocks for a few years now, and there's this question that always comes up when I start working on a new block:

Do I build a dynamic block or a static block?

If you have built blocks before, you've likely faced the same decision. But what if you didn't have to choose?

Dynamic versus static

If you are unfamiliar with the terms dynamic and static, Joni Halabi wrote an excellent article on the WordPress Developer Blog explaining the differences. So, I won't dive into all the details here.

But in short, dynamic blocks don't store the complete HTML content of the block in the database, just the attributes. On the front end, those attributes are used to render the block using PHP.

Static blocks, on the other hand, store their HTML content in the database. So, even if you remove the plugin that registered the block, WordPress will still display whatever's in the database on the front end.

Both approaches have pros and cons, but dynamic blocks have become the go-to for most developers because they give you more flexibility.

Check out Joni's article for more information and a review of the technical differences.

The problem

Calling a block dynamic or static is a convenient shorthand for how a block stores and renders content. If you understand these terms, then using this terminology is perfectly fine.

However, this naming convention has led many block developers, especially those just starting out, to believe there are only two ways to build a block.

This is incorrect.

A block can be dynamic and static simultaneously, and depending on your use case, this might be the best approach.

The solution

Consider the example of a copyright data block. This block displays the copyright symbol and the current year. The output will look like this:

Rendering the content of a block in PHP is extremely useful from a developer's perspective. If the markup or design of the block needs to be altered, you can easily make an update to the render function, and all blocks on the site will be updated.

Saving the HTML content of a block in the database is great for data integrity. If the block plugin is uninstalled, or the user wants to transfer the content to another site, the correct HTML content will display on the front end (minus any custom styles) even if the block no longer exists.

Consider the example of a copyright data block. This block displays the copyright symbol and the current year. The output will look like this:

In the Editor, this is the markup that will be saved if I was purely creating a dynamic block with no save function. 

<!-- wp:outermost/copyright-date-block {"showStartingYear":true,"startingYear":"2012","className":"wp-block-outermost-copyright-date-block"} /-->

By adding a save function, the markup now actually includes the HTML that renders the copyright date. 

<!-- wp:outermost/copyright-date-block {"showStartingYear":true,"startingYear":"2012"} -->
<p class="wp-block-outermost-copyright-date-block">© 2012–2023</p>
<!-- /wp:outermost/copyright-date-block -->

If I uninstall the Copyright Date Block plugin, the HTML will still display on the front end, and I will get a notice in the Editor that the block no longer exists. I can then click "Keep as HTML" and easily convert the content into a Paragraph block.

Depending on the type of block that you are building, taking the extra step to implement a save function can be extremely beneficial to users.

Just a block

In writing this post, I don't think the block development community needs to stop using the terms dynamic and static, but more education about what these terms mean is important. Focusing on a singular approach has tradeoffs, and other are many times that utilizing both a save functional a render.php file can be useful. You can architect blocks in multiple ways, but at the end of the day, a block is just a block.

item.title: How to change the Navigation block mobile icon in WordPress
item.dc:creator: ndiego
item.content:encoded:
I recently needed to change the icon used in the Navigation block on mobile devices. By default, you can choose between displaying text that reads Menu/Close, or one of two "hamburger" menu icons. The close icon is the same for both.

Three-Bar

Two-Bar

Close

While there is some discussion about how this functionality could be expanded in Core, you can easily modify the icon on the front end using the HTML API and the WP_HTML_Tag_Processor.

The block markup

Below is a simplified example of the HTML markup for the Navigation block when the three-bar icon is selected. Notice how there are two button elements, each containing an svg. The goal is to modify the d attribute in each path with my own icons, specifically chevrons.

Open

Close

<nav class="wp-block-navigation">
    <button class="wp-block-navigation__responsive-container-open">
        <svg width="24" height="24" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" viewBox="0 0 24 24">
            <path d="M5 5v1.5h14V5H5zm0 7.8h14v-1.5H5v1.5zM5 19h14v-1.5H5V19z"></path>
        </svg>
    </button>
    <div class="wp-block-navigation__responsive-container">
        <div class="wp-block-navigation__responsive-close">
            <div class="wp-block-navigation__responsive-dialog">
                <button class="wp-block-navigation__responsive-container-close">
                    <svg width="24" height="24" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" viewBox="0 0 24 24">
                        <path d="M13 11.8l6.1-6.3-1-1-6.1 6.2-6.1-6.2-1 1 6.1 6.3-6.5 6.7 1 1 6.5-6.6 6.5 6.6 1-1z"></path>
                    </svg>
                </button>
                <div class="wp-block-navigation__responsive-container-content">
                    <ul class="wp-block-navigation__container has-small-font-size is-responsive wp-block-navigation has-small-font-size">
                        ...                    
                    </ul>
                </div>
            </div>
        </div>
    </div>
</nav>

I chose the three-bar icon since its svg includes a path. The two-bar icon is made up of two rect, making things a bit more tricky. Users will never see the icon, so might as well use the one that is easier to modify.

As such, the following technique assumes your icon has a single path, but that's pretty easy to accomplish in most situations.

Using the HTML tag processor

The HTML API allows you to adjust HTML attributes in block markup using PHP. Introduced in WordPress 6.2, this API includes the WP_HTML_Tag_Processor which makes switching out the d attribute in each path simple. No need for regular expressions and the like.

I'll start by creating a simple render_block filter and add a check to make sure I'm only filtering Navigation blocks. 

function custom_mobile_icon_for_navigation( $block_content, $block ) {

    // Make sure we are filtering a Navigation block.
    if ( $block['blockName'] === 'core/navigation' ) {
        // Do something here...
    }

    // Do nothing, just return the block HTML.
    return $block_content;
}
add_filter( 'render_block', 'custom_mobile_icon_for_navigation', 10, 2 );

If you are not familiar with render_block, I suggest you read up on it after this article. It's one of the most useful filters for block development. Without it, my Block Visibility plugin would not be possible.

Next, I need to create a new WP_HTML_Tag_Processor and pass it the HTML of the block, which is the $block_content variable.

Take a look at the HTML of the block above. See that there is no unique identifier for each svg and definitely no identified for path. Without any additional information, the processor will replace all the d attribute in all each path. Since I want a different icon for open and close, I need to first differentiate between the two. Notice that each button does have a unique class.

When using next_tag, you can either pass an HTML tag name or an array that includes the tag_name, the class_name, or both.

Using both, I can target the open button like so:

$tag_processor->next_tag( array( 
    'tag_name'   => 'button', 
    'class_name' => 'wp-block-navigation__responsive-container-open' 
) )

Then, I need to target the path that's inside of the button. There is only one path in the three-bar hamburger icon, so the conditional is relatively straightforward. Then, all I need to do is set the d attribute using set_attribute. 

if ( 
    $tag_processor->next_tag( array( 
        'tag_name'.  => 'button', 
        'class_name' => 'wp-block-navigation__responsive-container-open' 
    ) )
    && $tag_processor->next_tag( 'path' )
) {
    $tag_processor->set_attribute( 'd', 'M17.5 11.6L12 16l-5.5-4.4.9-1.2L12 14l4.5-3.6 1 1.2z' );
}

Next, repeat this process for the close button. Putting it all together, the following code will change the open and close icons in the Navigation block to chevrons. 

function custom_mobile_icon_for_navigation( $block_content, $block ) {

    // Start by making sure we are filtering a Navigation block.
    if ( $block['blockName'] === 'core/navigation' ) {

        $tag_processor = new WP_HTML_Tag_Processor( $block_content );

        // Next, make sure we are targeting the correct class.
        if ( 
            $tag_processor->next_tag( array( 
                'tag_name' => 'div', 
                'class_name' => 'custom-icon-navigation-block' 
            ) )
        ) {

            // Change the path of the open icon.
            if ( 
                $tag_processor->next_tag( array( 
                    'tag_name' => 'button', 
                    'class_name' => 'wp-block-navigation__responsive-container-open' 
                ) )
                && $tag_processor->next_tag( 'path' )
            ) {
                $tag_processor->set_attribute( 'd', 'M17.5 11.6L12 16l-5.5-4.4.9-1.2L12 14l4.5-3.6 1 1.2z' );
            }

            // Change the path of the close icon.
            if ( 
                $tag_processor->next_tag( array( 
                    'tag_name' => 'button', 
                    'class_name' => 'wp-block-navigation__responsive-container-close' 
                ) )
                 && $tag_processor->next_tag( 'path' )
            ) {
                $tag_processor->set_attribute( 'd', 'M6.5 12.4L12 8l5.5 4.4-.9 1.2L12 10l-4.5 3.6-1-1.2z' );
            }
            
            // Return the updated HTML.
            return $tag_processor->get_updated_html();
        }
    }

    // Do nothing, just return the block HTML.
    return $block_content;
}
add_filter( 'render_block', 'custom_mobile_icon_for_navigation', 10, 2 );

item.title: Building block themes with WordPress Playground
item.dc:creator: ndiego
item.content:encoded:
A couple of years ago, I built the block theme that runs this site. It's called Nautilus and is in dire need of updating. WordPress has progressed so much in the last few years, and the theme does not take advantage of many of these improvements.

At the same time, I've been experimenting with WordPress Playground and pushing it to its limits. While chatting with Adam Zieliński (the creator) during a recent team meetup, he shared how you can leverage Playground and the Create Block Theme plugin for no-code theme development.

Playground acts as a local development environment and Create Block Theme handles the theme updates. Once changes are made, you can use Playground to submit a pull request back to the GitHub repository containing the theme.

Intrigued, I knew I had to try this with Nautilus.

The steps are detailed below, but I encourage you to watch the following video first. It helps conceptualize what this workflow.

[Video]

Let me set the stage for how this works.

The source code for Nautilus is stored in GitHub. In that repository, I can create a blueprint.json file, which tells Playground how to scaffold a WordPress site. In this case, I want it to install and activate the Nautilus theme and the Create Block Theme plugin.

Plumbing

  • Create a blueprint.json file for the theme
  • Use the GitHub Proxy
  • Create the Edit link
{
	"step": "installTheme",
	"themeZipFile": {
		"resource": "url",
		"url": "https://github-proxy.com/proxy/?repo=ndiego/nautilus"
	}
},
{
	"step": "mv",
	"fromPath": "/wordpress/wp-content/themes/nautilus-main",
	"toPath": "/wordpress/wp-content/themes/nautilus"
},
{
	"step": "activateTheme",
	"themeFolderName": "nautilus"
},

When using the proxy is generate a zip, the folder name becomes the repo-branch. The repository name/slug for Nautilus is nautilus, so if I use the proxy for the main branch, the zip folder becomes nautilus-main.

When the theme is installed, this will also be the theme folder name, which is not ideal and can pose some issues when you go to generate PRs. Therefore, I copied the contents of the nautilus-main to a new folder called nautilus. This is easy to do with the mv step in Playground.

Then finally active the theme using the activeTheme step and make sure you are pointing to the new folder.

Caveats

This workflow relies on the functionality built into the Create Block Theme. You won't be able to add block variations, per-block stylesheets, etc. But that's not the intent. If you are developing a block theme for a client or public disribution, you will almost certainly still use a local development environment like Studio or Local. But, being able to add a simply link to your GitHub repository (or anywhere else) that allows protective contributors and effortless way to propose changes to the theme is amazing. Perhaps your traveling and new pattern idea pops in your head.

item.title: A few of my favorite blueprint steps for WordPress Playground
item.dc:creator: ndiego
item.content:encoded:
Set your display name and avatar

When I launch a Playground instance, especially if I need to take a screenshot or record a video demo, my name and Gravatar need to be displayed in the admin bar. The wp-cli step saves the day again.

{
    "step": "wp-cli",
    "command": "wp user update 1 --display_name='First Last' --user_email='your-gravatar@email.com'"
}

Note that your user ID will always be 1 by default in Playground. This is helpful for the next tip.

Set user meta

The first thing I do on a new WordPress site is change the admin color scheme to "Modern". This reflects the new branding on WordPress.org and it just feels right to me. Thankfully, you can easily define this using the updateUserMetadata step.

{
    "step": "updateUserMeta",
    "meta": {
        "admin_color": "modern",
        "show_welcome_panel": 0
    },
    "userId": 1
},

You can also set other user meta fields. In the code above, I've disabled the Dashboard welcome message.

Set the view mode

Playground provides a browser UI.

Try it out using the buttons below.

Default
Seamless

Create a personal blueprint library

I fundamentally believe WordPress Playground is going to become ubiquitous in our community.

While I still use tools like Local and Studio for local development, Playground has become my solution when I need to test WordPress, record demos, etc.

The only time I use a local site now is when I'm actually writing code.

Therefore, I have begun to curate my own personal collection of blueprints for various purposes.

item.title: Blockifying a WordPress plugin I wrote eight years ago
item.dc:creator: ndiego
item.content:encoded:
The year was 2016. WordPress 4.5 "Coleman" was about to be released on April 12th, and I was putting the finishing touches on a small plugin called Easy Plugin Stats.

The idea was simple: the plugin would register a shortcode to display the stats of a plugin hosted on WordPress.org. Here's an example.

[ eps slug="easy-plugin-stats" field="active_installs"]

The extra space prevents the shortcode from rendering.

I originally built the plugin for myself. On my Projects page, I wanted to show an overview of the plugins and themes I'm working on, including the current number of downloads and active installs for each one in the directory.

Developing the shortcode was relatively easy since you can fetch plugin data from the WordPress Plugins API. To avoid the hassle of configuring shortcodes manually, I also built a TinyMCE plugin with a user-friendly shortcode builder.

Remember the Editor in these days?

I was quite proud of that TinyMCE plugin back in 2016. It was early in my WordPress development journey, and I remember struggling with the JavaScript. The code was rough, but it worked.

Fast-forward to 2024. I'd become increasingly frustrated by this plugin. In addition to this site, I use Easy Plugin Stats on blockvisibilitywp.com. Everything is a block on both sites except for the plugin stats shortcode. Here's what the Editor looked like for my Projects page. Horrendous.

As a fully sponsored WordPress Developer Advocate whose primary job involves promoting block development and supporting adoption, "blockifying" Easy Plugin Stats was embarrassingly long overdue.

The approach

Backward compatibility is paramount, especially with plugins hosted in the Plugin Directory. Therefore, I wanted to keep the shortcode, but the TinyMCE plugin could go.

The block

Before diving into the block and the Button block variation, here's a preview of the end result.

Easy Plugin Stats

Easily display stats associated with plugins hosted on WordPress.org, such as the number of downloads, active installations, star rating, and more.

Download
Live Preview

The block

Since the plugin would include a shortcode, block, and block variation that would all render similar output, I decided to build a dynamically rendered block. This would allow it to share PHP functions with the shortcode and variation. In fact the fontend output of the

I used the create-block package with the --no-plugin and --variant dynamic flags to scaffold a dynamic block within the existing Easy Plugin Stats plugin. If you take a look at the code, you'll notice that I opted for using a callback function instead of a render.php file. This made things a bit simpler, given the unique structure of this plugin.

I toyed with the idea of just displaying placeholder content in the Editor, but this does not provide a great editing experience. You want to actually see the stats for each plugin.

Therefore, I used the FormTokenField component to allow users to set the plugin slug or slugs (more on that in a minute). Once set, the plugin data is fetched from the WordPress.org Plugins API, and the user can choose which field to display using a SelectControl component.

The shortcode supports aggregate stats for downloads and active_installs. So if you provide multiple slugs like in the image above, and choose a stat that supports aggregation, the data for each plugin will be fetched and added together.

The shortcode also includes an option to display HTML before or after the stat. I wanted to emulate this idea in the block and ended up using the

The block variation

Previously, there was no easy way to add dynamic plugin links to buttons. For example, the download link for a plugin changes with each new version, so I would have to manually update each button.

Now I could have added a button variant to the Plugin Stat block, but why not use the Button block that's already in WordPress?

The Block Bindings API was introduced in WordPress 6.5, which allows you to "bind" data to block attributes. You will often use this with post metadata (custom fields), but you can also define custom binding sources. Justin Tadlock wrote several excellent articles on the topic on the WordPress Developer Blog.

The API is currently limited to specific Core blocks and attributes, but the url attribute of the Button block is one of the support attributes. This is perfect, because I want to bind plugin links fetched from the WordPress.org Plugins API to the url attribute of a button.

Justin's article goes into much more detail, but you start by resisting a custom binding source using the register_block_bindings_source function. 

register_block_bindings_source(
	'easy-plugin-stats/button',
	array(
		'label'              => __( 'Plugin Button Binding', 'easy-plugin-stats' ),
		'get_value_callback' => __NAMESPACE__ . '\bindings_callback',
	)
);

The source is easy-plugin-stats/button and the callback function is used to update the URL of the button link on the front end. The function is quite simple since it relies on get_remote_plugin_data() and get_field_output() to generate the output.

function bindings_callback( $source_args ) {
	
	// Bail if there is no plugin slug.
	if ( ! ( $source_args['slug'] ?? null ) ) {
		return null;
	}

	// Fetch the plugin data.
	$plugin_data = get_remote_plugin_data( $source_args['slug'], $source_args['cache'] ?? null );

	return get_field_output( $source_args, $plugin_data, true, false );
}

At this point, the custom block binding is complete, but it needs to be manually applied to each block. Here's an example of a Button block that will link to the download_link for the Easy Plugin Stats plugin.

<!-- wp:button {"metadata":{"bindings":{"url":{"source":"easy-plugin-stats/button","args":{"field":"download_link","slug":"easy-plugin-stats"}}}},"className":"is-style-fill"} -->
<div class="wp-block-button is-style-fill"><a class="wp-block-button__link wp-element-button">Download</a></div>
<!-- /wp:button -->

Manually setting these metadata attributes is a pain, and while we may see a native UI for custom block bindings in the future, you can easily create them yourself. This also gives you full control over how the UI is implemented.

The best approach that I have found used block variations. So, create a simple variation that pre-sets the metadata attribute. Make sure to set the isActive attribute so the Editor will indicate the Button variation is a "Plugin Button" as long as it has the correct metadata attribute.

This is a simplified version of the variation in the plugin. 

registerBlockVariation( 'core/button', {
	name: 'easy-plugin-stats/button',
	title: __( 'Plugin Button', 'easy-plugin-stats' ),
	scope: [ 'inserter' ],
	attributes: {
		metadata: {
			bindings: {
				url: {
					source: 'easy-plugin-stats/button',
					args: {
						field: 'download_link',
						slug: '',
					},
				},
			},
		},
	},
	isActive: ( blockAttributes ) =>
		'easy-plugin-stats/button' ===
		blockAttributes?.metadata?.bindings?.url?.source,
} );

This works great, but now you need a way for the user to set define the plugin slug and the field they want to use. For this, I used the editor.BlockEdit and conditionally displayed a custom Panel component if the selected block is a Button and has the correct metadata attribute, which is defined automatically when you insert the block variation. 

function addInspectorControls( BlockEdit ) {
	return ( props ) => {
		// Bail early if the Button block does not have the correct binding.
		if (
			props?.name === 'core/button' &&
			props?.attributes?.metadata?.bindings?.url?.source ===
				'easy-plugin-stats/button'
		) {
			return (
				<>
					<BlockEdit { ...props } />
					<Panel { ...props } />
				</>
			);
		}
		return <BlockEdit { ...props } />;
	};
}

addFilter(
	'editor.BlockEdit',
	'easy-plugin-stats/add-inspector-controls',
	addInspectorControls
);

The Panel component itself is straightforward so I won't cover that here.

Putting it all together, the

Taking it a step further

The Button variation works well, but it's common to want an icon next to the button text, especially for download links. Instead of adding this feature to the Easy Plugin Stats variation, I used another plugin I created called Enable Button Icons. This experimental plugin is available on GitHub.

Once installed and activated, a new panel will appear in the block inspector for each Button block. You can select an icon and choose whether it appears before or after the button text.

One benefit of using block bindings instead of custom blocks is that other third-party extensions will automatically work with your new functionality.

While I'm a strong proponent of custom block development, consider whether a block extension or variation might be better before starting. This approach lets you focus on the unique features your plugin offers while relying on WordPress to handle the default functionality.

Final thoughts

While Easy Plugin Stats is now more complicated under the hood, the user experience is vastly improved. All the extra work I put into version 2.0 was worth it. No more fiddling with shortcode settings or the pain of seeing your beautiful block design ruined by shortcode markup.

But I still think there are times when shortcodes are useful, at least for now. They're the easiest way to show that my plugins are running on [eps type="aggregate" slug="icon-block social-sharing-block easy-plugin-stats block-visibility blox-lite genesis-columns-advanced genesis-custom-headers genesis-featured-page-advanced" field="active_installs"]+ sites right in the middle of this Paragraph block.

I do recognize that spending the time and resources to rebuild plugins is not always economical. This is especially true when working with client budgets.

However, as WordPress developers, we should be looking for every opportunity to move away from shortcodes and other "legacy" technologies. My friend Ryan Welcher and I recently shared tips on metabox alternatives during WordPress Developer Hours.

The more we embrace this mentality and push the limits of custom blocks and Editor extensibility, the quicker we can move WordPress forward, close any gaps, and give users a fantastic editing experience.

So, what do you think? Is there anything in WordPress that's preventing you from adopting a similar approach?

item.title: The age of bespoke WordPress plugins
item.dc:creator: ndiego
item.content:encoded:
WordPress development, especially plugin development, is changing rabidly with the introduction of AI tools. My current go-to is Cursor. At this point, when I start working on a new project, I begin by sketching out a prompt, often in a instructions.md file.

While I'm a bit proponent of plugin and block development, I actually rarely use plugins that I have not written myself. Exceptions being things like Jetpack and Yoast.

But if I need a new block, or tweak an existing block, I write it myself. Now historically this approach takes a fair amount of knowledge, and crucially, time.

Time to read up on documentation. Time to learn a new API. Time to miticulously tweak styling. Time to actually write the code.

Even the simplest task, with scaffolding tools like create-block, would take days to build.

As a result, I, like many of you would default to exsiting solutions. For example, on this site I need syntax highlighting for the Code block. I knew I could build this myself, but who has the time? Instead, I settled on a great plugin called Syntax Code Highlighter by Marcus XXX.

While this plugin works, it's not exactly what I wanted and includes functionality that I don't need. It also doesn't include things like a copy button.

I've sufficiently buried the lead, but what if time wasn't a factor? What if you could build a bespoke plugins that does exactly what you want?

Enter AI.

So, with Cursor by my side, I sat down and started to sketch out what I wanted.

  • Extend the code Code block
  • Allows the user to choose the code langauge and a title, copy button, a line numbers
  • Remove unnecessary block supports
  • Make the extension feel as much like core WordPress as possible

item.title: Effortlessly deploying code on GitHub to production
item.dc:creator: ndiego
item.content:encoded:
Like most WordPress developers, I have a lot of code on GitHub. Everything from plugin's I've released on WordPress.org and experimental blocks to utility plugins and custom WordPress themes.

While some were created for educational purposes as part of my Developer Relations role, many I actively use on my personal sites or those I've built for others. The challenge has always been getting that code on those sites in a manner that was easily updatable. Other than the plugins hosted on WordPress.org, this process would involve manually uploading new copies to each site.

Now many WordPress hosts do provide methods to deploy code from GitHub to production or staging sites, but I've always found them clunky to setup and often not worth the time especially for a couple plugins and maybe a theme.

That changed in January when I moved my personal site (this one) to WordPress.com.

Backstory sdf

Now before I continue, I want to be candid that I work for Automattic, the company behind WordPress.com. But, I will be the first one to conceed that WordPress.com has not had a strong reputation in the WordPress developer community. It's simply not been a primary focus, instead targeting individuals looking to start blogs, personal sites, etc.

Being an employee of Automattic, I spent some time exploring the various developer tools that WordPress.com provides, and stumbled upon GitHub Deployments. I trully had no idea we offered this functionality, which is partly the reason I'm writing about it now.

The tool is dead simple, and does exactly what I have been wanting. It was the primary reason I migrated to WordPress.com.

Here's how it works:

  • You need a Business or Commerce hosting account on WordPress.com
  • Connect your site to your GitHub account
  • Choose which repositories you want to make available for deployment. You can choose all or a specific subset.
  • Determine how the sync should work.

So, if you are currently using another host, great. This post is not meant to entice you to switch to WordPress.com. But if you are already hosted on the platform and you are a developer with code on GitHub, give GitHub Deployments a try. You won't regret it.

Is WordPress.com perfect? Absolutely not. Did I like Pressable more, on the whole? Yes.

But, behind the scenes, mountains are moving and I'm truly excited about the direction we are heading.

As a Developer Advocate, honesty and transparency are key. Yes, I am employed by Automattic, but it doesn't benefit anyone if I'm not truthful about the products I create content on. This site is powered by WordPRess.com. All my custom plugins and the theme powering this site use GitHub Deployments.

item.title: A change of direction
item.dc:creator: ndiego
item.content:encoded:
I've had my personal website for a number of years now and never did much with it.

When my name was Googled, or someone used one of my WordPress plugins, I wanted a place where they could learn more about me and the projects I was working on. But that was about it.

As a self-taught web developer, the internet has been my classroom. I am a strong believer that there are very few questions that cannot be answered with a well-crafted Google search. There are so many great resources today and tons of content creators openly sharing their knowledge to help others. This is one of the things that drew me to the open-source nature of WordPress in 2014. The community surrounding the platform was welcoming and the knowledge needed to work with WordPress was accessible.

I eventually stumbled upon the Genesis Framework, a theme framework for WordPress. Yes, the Genesis themes looked great, but it was the underlying codebase that impressed me. Everything was so well documented and allowed a beginner like me to easily understand what was going on. The Genesis community, similar to WordPress as a whole, offered a wealth of freely available content. I was able to quickly level up my development and design skills from the likes of Bill Erickson, Carrie Dils, Brian Gardner, and Rafal Tomal.

In fact, the design of this site was heavily influenced by Rafal's work and Brian's approach to minimalistic design.

Today, WordPress development is getting more complex. Success increasingly requires modern web development skills and fluency in advanced javascript. Gone are the days when you only needed to know HMTL, CSS, and PHP. This transition has decreased the accessibility of WordPress for aspiring self-taught developers. However, the modernization of the platform is necessary and allows WordPress to remain competitive with other heavily marketed companies like Squarespace and Wix.

With so many changes coming to WordPress, and the official documentation struggling to keep up, the need for knowledge sharing in the community is even more important these days.

So, back to the purpose of this website.

Moving forward, I intend to be more diligent about documenting and sharing information that I acquire through my own WordPress education. There are so many exciting developments on the horizon, from full-site editing to the increased adoption of the Gutenberg "Block" Editor. Being successful in this digital arena will require mastery of these new tools and I hope this blog will serve as another community resource. There may also be a few posts on the intersection of WordPress, marketing, and hospitality given my 18+ years in the industry.

Whether this content is useful to a larger audience or not, it's always just one Google search away.

Thanks for stopping by.

item.title: Programmatically add classes to blocks in the WordPress editor based on attributes
item.dc:creator: ndiego
item.content:encoded:
Overview

When working with custom attributes in the WordPress block editor, you may want to add a specific CSS class to block components based on the value of your attributes.

In my example, I wanted to add the class block-visibility__is-hidden to every block that had the hideBlock attribute set to true. I could then style these blocks as needed in the editor so users could visually see which blocks were hidden.

This post will detail how adding block classes based on custom attributes can be achieved. Note that we will not be covering how to add classes to blocks on the front end of your site, just the block editor. Jump to the summary if you are just looking for the solution.

Setup

I am assuming you are familiar with JavaScript (ESNext), React and have an appropriate development environment for your project. If you are not, or need a refresher, check out the Tutorials in the Block Editor Handbook.

To add custom classes to blocks in the editor, you need to use the editor.BlockListBlock filter. More information on this filter, and block filters in general, can be found in the Block Editor Handbook.

The first thing you need to do is add the filter. All filters have the following format addFilter( 'hookName/filterName', 'namespace', callback, priority ). But, before you can actually use this function, you need to import it into your project from the @wordpress/hooks module. See below for what the end result will look like.

/**
 * WordPress dependencies
 */
import { addFilter } from '@wordpress/hooks';

addFilter(
	'editor.BlockListBlock',
	'your-plugin/your-custom-class',
	withYourCustomBlockClass
);

In this example, we don't need to worry too much about priority, but you can add it if you need to down the line.

Next, you need to create the callback function, which will be a higher-order component of the BlockListBlock component. BlockListBlock "wraps" around every block component in the WordPress editor and applies various properties and classes. We will be using the handy createHigherOrderComponent function to accomplish this, which can be imported from the @wordpress/compose module. The initial setup without any customizations should look something like the following.

/**
 * WordPress dependencies
 */
import { addFilter } from '@wordpress/hooks';
import { createHigherOrderComponent } from '@wordpress/compose';

const withYourCustomBlockClass = createHigherOrderComponent( ( BlockListBlock ) => {
    return ( props ) => {
        return <BlockListBlock { ...props }/>;
    };
}, 'withYourCustomBlockClass' );

addFilter(
	'editor.BlockListBlock',
	'your-plugin/your-custom-class',
	withYourCustomBlockClass
);

Customizations

Now that the filter is completely setup, you can start adding the desired customizations to your withYourCustomBlockClass function.

Adding a class

To add a custom class, you simply add a className attribute to the BlockListBlock component.

const withYourCustomBlockClass = createHigherOrderComponent( ( BlockListBlock ) => {
    return ( props ) => {
        return <BlockListBlock { ...props } className={ 'your-custom-class' }/>;
    };
}, 'withYourCustomBlockClass' );

This will add your-custom-class to every block in the editor. While this is likely not the outcome you are looking for, it's a good start.

Adding a class based on an attribute

To display the class based on an attribute, you need to retrieve the block attributes from props. Assume that the custom attribute is named customAttribute and you want to add the custom class if the attribute exists on the block, and it's value is true. The code would look something like this.

const withYourCustomBlockClass = createHigherOrderComponent( ( BlockListBlock ) => {
    return ( props ) => {
        const { attributes } = props;
        const { customAttribute } = attributes;
        const customClass = customAttribute ? 'your-custom-class' : '';

        return <BlockListBlock { ...props } className={ customClass }/>;
    };
}, 'withYourCustomBlockClass' );

Again, this filter will target every block in the editor but will only add the class if the block has customAttribute set to true. Of course, your attributes could be much more complicated than a simple boolean, and you could apply different custom classes based on the value(s) of each attribute.

Limit the custom class to selected blocks

In the examples above, we have targeted every block type in the editor. What if you only want to add a custom class to a specific block type or a group of blocks?

The props variable contains pretty much everything you need to know about a block, including its name. Try console.log( props ); and you will see all the information that is available to you. Because of this, there's tons of "filtering" you can do.

Assume you only want to add your-custom-class to paragraph blocks. You would then do something like the following. If the block does not have the appropriate name, you just return the unedited BlockListBlock component.

const withYourCustomBlockClass = createHigherOrderComponent( ( BlockListBlock ) => {
    return ( props ) => {
        const { name, attributes } = props;

        if ( name != 'core/paragraph' ) {
            return <BlockListBlock { ...props }/>;
        }

        const { customAttribute } = attributes;
        const customClass = customAttribute ? 'your-custom-class' : '';

        return <BlockListBlock { ...props } className={ customClass }/>;
    };
}, 'withYourCustomBlockClass' );

While this is a simple example, you can get much more sophisticated in the blocks you are filtering out. In my Block Visibility project, there is an entire function dedicated to determining which block(s) should have the block-visibility__is-hidden class.

Summary

This post gave you a quick overview of how you can add custom classes to blocks in the WordPress editor based on block attributes and also depending on the block type (name). This should give you a good starting point for your projects.

Below is the complete code for adding the CSS class your-custom-class to all paragraph blocks if the block has the custom attribute yourAttribute set to true. Of course, paragraph blocks do not naturally have this attribute, so you would need to add it for this example code to do anything useful. But that is a post for another time.

/**
 * WordPress dependencies
 */
import { addFilter } from '@wordpress/hooks';
import { createHigherOrderComponent } from '@wordpress/compose';

const withYourCustomBlockClass = createHigherOrderComponent( ( BlockListBlock ) => {
    return ( props ) => {
        const { name, attributes } = props;

        if ( name != 'core/paragraph' ) {
            return <BlockListBlock { ...props }/>;
        }
	
	const { yourAttribute } = attributes;
	const customClass = yourAttribute ? 'your-custom-class' : '';

        return <BlockListBlock { ...props } className={ customClass } />;
    };
}, 'withYourCustomBlockClass' );

addFilter(
	'editor.BlockListBlock',
	'your-plugin/your-custom-class',
	withYourCustomBlockClass
);

item.title: Activating a license in React for EDD Software Licensing while avoiding CORS issues
item.dc:creator: ndiego
item.content:encoded:
If you have ever written a WordPress plugin or theme with the ultimate goal of selling this content, you most likely stumbled upon Easy Digital Downloads, or EDD for short. EDD is my marketplace software of choice and was purpose-built to sell, well, digital downloads, making it perfect for WordPress developers.

EDD has a number of add-ons, including the Software Licensing add-on. This allows you to sell a product and provide a license key to the purchaser. In your plugin or theme, the user can then activate the license, which will enable automatic downloads and any additional functionality that you have developed.

The process of activating a license is pretty straight forward, and EDD provides a number of examples, and even a sample plugin and theme, which shows you exactly how to get this all set up.

So what's the problem?

JavaScript (React)

JavaScript (React) is becoming increasingly important for WordPress development, especially with the introduction of the new Block Editor and full-site editing on the horizon. Therefore, in my Block Visibility project, I wanted to build an admin settings page in React as opposed to the normal method using PHP. This meant that the license activation would take place in a React component, which was exciting since it provided the opportunity to improve the activation UI. I was never that happy with previous implementations I had done in PHP.

EDD conveniently had an example of how to activate licenses in pure JavaScript. This would be a quick port to React, so I figured the whole process would be quite simple.

At this point, it is important to mention that I am a self-taught developer, and there are some holes in my "education". Seasoned developers may have been able to spot the impending issue right away, but hopefully, many of you will find my trials and tribulations insightful.

In very general terms, when a user activates a license, they are sending a "request" back to the website that they purchased the product from, which will return a "response" indicating if the activation was successful or not. Enter CORS:

Cross-origin resource sharing (CORS) is a mechanism that allows restricted resources on a web page to be requested from another domain outside the domain from which the first resource was served.

Wikipedia

Making a resource request between two websites can inherently have security implications. You don't want just anyone requesting license information, which includes some customer data, from your online store. If you try activating a license using the JavaScript example that EDD provides, there is a chance that you will get an error similar to the one below:

My store website did not have a HTTP response header set which resulted in this CORS error. There are of course ways to add a header to your server, Mozilla has a nice writeup about this, but none of the options seemed reasonable from a convenience or security perspective. I am not trying to create a public API, and I don't want my project to rely on a specific server configuration to work properly.

The saving grace here is that this issue really only impacts client-side requests, i.e. requests made in JavaScript. If the license activation request is made in PHP or server-side, you are able to bypass the CORS policy. This is by design, and there is a ton more information about CORS that you can find with a quick Google search. Too much to even try and dissect in this post.

The solution: Ajax

Making the license request directly from JavaScript was a no-go for my setup, so I needed to head back to PHP. However, I still wanted all my license activation UI in React. The solution is to write a PHP function that handles the request and uses Ajax to invoke this function from React. Ajax is used pretty frequently in WordPress, but generally with jQuery. This was my first time making an Ajax call in React.

Enqueueing Scripts

To get started, we need to append some variables to our project's JavaScript file using the wp_add_inline_script function. The two variables we need to add are the URL for the admin-ajax.php and a security token, or a nonce. The implementation would look something like the following.

function demo_enqueue_project_scripts() {

	...

	wp_enqueue_script(
		'demo-setting-scripts',
		plugin_dir_url( __FILE__ ) . 'dist/demo-settings.js',
		array( 'wp-api' ), // Array of dependancies (Optional depending on your needs)
		$version, // Script version (Optional depending on your needs)
		true // Enqueue the file in the footer (Optional depending on your needs)
	);

	// Variables for running the license controls ajax request.
	$variables = 'const demoAjaxUrl = ' . wp_json_encode( admin_url( 'admin-ajax.php' ) ) . ';';
	$variables .= 'const demoLicenseControlsNonce = ' . wp_json_encode( wp_create_nonce( 'demo-license-controls-nonce' ) ) . ';';

	wp_add_inline_script(
		'demo-setting-scripts',
		$variables,
		'before'
	);

	...
}
add_action( 'admin_enqueue_scripts', 'demo_enqueue_project_scripts' );

PHP Function

Next, we need to write the PHP function that will actually handle the license activation/deactivation request to the store website. Before I dive into the particulars, here is what this function should roughly look like. I do recommend reviewing the EDD Software Licensing API documentation. The function below is based on the sample plugin that is provided by EDD when you purchase the Software Licensing add-on.

function demo_license_controls() {

	check_ajax_referer( 'demo-license-controls-nonce' );

	$api_url    = 'https://www.demostore.com';
	$item_name  = 'Demo Plugin';
	$item_id    = 1234;
	$edd_action = sanitize_text_field( $_POST['edd_action'] );
        $license    = sanitize_text_field( $_POST['license'] );

	// Data to send to the API
	$api_params = array(
		'edd_action' => $edd_action,
		'license'    => $license,
		'item_name'  => urlencode( $item_name ),
		'item_id'    => BVP_ITEM_ID,
		'url'        => home_url()
	);

	// Call the API
	$response = wp_remote_post(
		$api_url,
		array(
			'timeout'   => 15,
			'sslverify' => false,
			'body'      => $api_params
		)
	);

	// Make sure there are no errors
	if (
		is_wp_error( $api_response ) ||
		200 !== intval( wp_remote_retrieve_response_code( $api_response ) )
	)
		wp_die( __( 'There has been an error retrieving the license information from the server, perhaps you are no longer connected to the internet. Please contact support.', 'demo-text-domain' ) );
	}

	// There are no errors, so retrieve the response
	echo wp_remote_retrieve_body( $response );

	wp_die();
}
add_action( 'wp_ajax_demo_license_controls', 'demo_license_controls' );

The first thing I am doing in this function is validating the nonce. We do not want to proceed with this API call if there is no valid security token.

The $api_url variable is the URL for the website with EDD Software Licensing running on it, i.e. the product store. The $item_name and $item_id refer to the product the user is attempting to activate. Refer to the documentation on where to find the id. Note that these variables are hardcoded for demonstration purposes, but you will likely come up with a more elegant solution.

Next, I am setting the $edd_action and $license key. These two variables come from the UI in React, and I will talk more about them later. Variables from JavaScript are passed to PHP via Ajax and are retrieved using the $_POST method in this example.

With all the variables set, we make the API call using wp_remote_post() which performs an HTTP request using the POST method. Assuming there are no errors, we then retrieve the response.

Note that there are other ways in PHP to make an HTTP request, but using all of the WordPress-specific functions makes debugging much easier, especially is_wp_error() and wp_die().

The most important part of the code above is the last line. There are two actions that we could use here. wp_ajax_(your action name) only works for users that are logged in to your website. wp_ajax_nopriv_(your action name) is for users that are not logged in. Both can be used in tandem, but since license activation takes place in the admin area of the website, we just need wp_ajax_(your action name).

The (your action name) part of the action, or demo_license_controls in this example, will be used in the Ajax call on the React side.

React Function

Finally, we need to make the Ajax call in React where the license activation UI "lives". First, a quick recap of the data flow we are attempting to create and what a user will actually be doing.

  1. The user will enter their license key into a text field and then click an "Activate" button.
  2. The license key value will then be passed to our PHP function via Ajax.
  3. The PHP function will make an API call to the store website to activate the license if it is activable.
  4. A response will be sent back with a success or failure message.
  5. We will then parse the response and display a message to the user about whether the activation was successful or not.

Steps 1 and 5 are outside the scope of this post but are pretty straightforward. WordPress does have a number of built-in components, such as text inputs and buttons, that I encourage you to check out. I am leveraging them in my projects, and the Developer Handbook provides a good overview of each one.

Step 2 is where we need to make our Ajax call. There are many different Ajax libraries that you could use, but I chose the Fetch API since it is built-in to all modern browsers and I did not want to include another library in my project. The function should look something like the following:

// Valid actions are activate_license, deactivate_license, get_version, check_license
async function licenseControls( license = '', edd_action = 'activate_license' ) {
	const response = await fetch( demoAjaxUrl, {
		method: 'POST',
		credentials: 'same-origin',
		headers: { 'Content-Type': 'application/x-www-form-urlencoded' },
		body: new URLSearchParams( {
			_ajax_nonce: demoLicenseControlsNonce,
			action: 'demo_license_controls',
			edd_action: edd_action,
			license: license,
		} )
	} );
	return response.json();
}

The function accepts two parameters, the license key, and the EDD action. This function can actually be used to activate a license, deactivate a license, check the status of a license, or get the current version number of the product, all based on the edd_action parameter.

You will note that we are fetching from the demoAjaxUrl, which we enqueued with our scripts earlier in this post. We are also using the nonce, demoLicenseControlsNonce, as one of the parameters.

Next, we have the action parameter set to demo_license_controls, which we set when adding our PHP function. And finally, we are passing the license and edd_action.

Now when the user clicks the "Activate" button, your React app will call the above function, which will return a JSON response. If the activation is successful, the response will look something like:

{
    "success": true,
    "license": "valid",
    "item_id": 1234
    "item_name": "Demo Plugin",
    "license_limit": 0,
    "site_count": 2,
    "expires": "2021-06-30 23:59:59",
    "activations_left": "unlimited",
    "checksum": "<MD$ Checksum>",
    "payment_id": 12345,
    "customer_name": "John Doe",
    "customer_email": "john@sample.org",
    "price_id": "2"
}

You can then use this data to provide a success notice to the user. EDD has examples of other response options if, for example, the activation fails or you are using a different EDD action.

Summary

The topics covered in this post are just the tip of the iceberg, but I hope it helps you overcome the CORS issue that I ran into when using the Software Licensing add-on for EDD. To simplify everything I wrote above into three bullet points:

  1. Create your license activation UI in React.
  2. Handle the actual license activation in a PHP function.
  3. Invoke the PHP function using Ajax from your React app.

That's it, mission complete!
